title: ICE `!ty.needs_infer() && !ty.has_placeholders()` from boxing closure of type dyn for<'a> _

labels.name: I-ICE
labels.description: Issue: The compiler panicked, giving an Internal Compilation Error (ICE) ❄️

labels.name: regression-from-stable-to-nightly
labels.description: Performance or correctness regression from stable to nightly.

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: regression-from-stable-to-beta
labels.description: Performance or correctness regression from stable to beta.

body:
While experimenting with clonable closures (and encountering like a thousand `one type is more general than the other` errors), I eventually discovered a scenario which crashes rustc.

I tried this code ([play](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=318132bfa4aa14aba2e834d2901df8f0):

```rust
trait ClonableFn<T> {
	fn clone(&self) -> Box<dyn Fn(T)>;
}

impl<T, F: 'static> ClonableFn<T> for F
where F: Fn(T) + Clone {
	fn clone(&self) -> Box<dyn Fn(T)> {
		Box::new(self.clone())
	}
}

struct Foo(Box<dyn for<'a> ClonableFn<&'a bool>>);

fn main() {
	Foo(Box::new(|_| ()));
}
```

I expected to see this happen: Actually, I am not sure ... Anyways, I guess I expected to see rustc surviving the input ...

## Meta

`rustc --version --verbose`:
rustc 1.33.0-nightly (c0bbc3927 2019-01-03)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: c0bbc3927e28c22edefe6a1353b5ecc95ea9a104
commit-date: 2019-01-03
host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 1.33.0-nightly
LLVM version: 8.0

Backtrace:
